pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:0.5: 48. The training rule on armies in action
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.1: On one occasion when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.2: King Pasenadi of Kosala was marching out with the army,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.3: and the monks from the group of six went to see the army in action.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.4: King Pasenadi saw those monks coming,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.5: and he summoned them and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.7: “We wish to see the great king.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.8: “What’s the use of seeing me finding pleasure in battle?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.10: And people complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.11: “How can the Sakyan ascetics go to see an army in action?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.12: It’s our misfortune that we must go out with the army for the sake of our livelihood and because of our wives and children.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.13: The monks heard the complaints of those people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.14: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.15: “How can the monks from the group of six go to see an army in action?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.16: “Is it true, monks, that you did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.19: “… Foolish men, how can you go to see an army in action?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.20: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.21: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.22.1: ‘If a monk goes to see an army in action, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:1.23: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:2.1: Soon afterwards a certain monk had a sick uncle in the army.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:2.2: The uncle sent a message to that monk:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:2.3: “I’m with the army and I’m sick.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:2.6: Knowing that the Buddha had laid down a rule against going to see an army in action, that monk thought,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:2.7: “I have an uncle in the army who is sick.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:2.10: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:2.11: “Monks, I allow you to go to the army when there’s a suitable reason.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:2.12: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:2.13.1: ‘If a monk goes to see an army in action, except if there is a suitable reason, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.1.6: it has left the inhabited area and is either encamped or marching.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.1.9: Each elephant has twelve men; each horse has three men; each chariot has four men; each unit of infantry has four men with arrows in hand.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.1.10: If he is on his way to see it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.1.11: Wherever he stands to see it, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.1.12: Every time he moves outside of the range of sight and then sees it again, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.1.13: Except if there is a suitable reason:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.1.14: unless there is a suitable reason.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.2.1: If it is in action, and he perceives it as such, and he goes to see it, except if there is a suitable reason, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.2.2: If it is in action, but he is unsure of it, and he goes to see it, except if there is a suitable reason, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.2.3: If it is in action, but he does not perceive it as such, and he goes to see it, except if there is a suitable reason, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.2.4: If he is on his way to see one division of a fourfold army, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.2.5: Wherever he stands to see it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.2.6: Every time he moves outside of the range of sight and then sees it again, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.2.7: If it is not in action, but he perceives it as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.2.8: If it is not in action, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.2.9: If it is not in action, and he does not perceive it as such, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.3.2: if he sees it while standing in the monastery;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.3.3: if the army comes to where the monk is standing, sitting, or lying down;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.3.4: if he sees it while walking in the opposite direction;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.3.5: if he has a suitable reason;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.3.8: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc48:3.3.9: The eighth rule, the training rule on armies in action, is finished.
